answers.answer: What quality of vision (20/x and how many diopters near/far) and/or type(s) of vision correction (glasses, contact) have you had in your right eye prior to the cataract?

I would STOP RIGHT NOW and get a second and third opinion on you situation. Rarely will we every set a post surgery goal of -7.00 refractive error especially if the other eye that is being "matched" does not see normally.As a generalization if you like reading without glasses then most surgeons would likely set the "good" eye at -2.75  +/- 0.25 diopters and do lasik on bad eye or IOL exchange.JCH MD
Seek a 2nd opinion, consider going with a totally new doctor.

question: I had cataract surgery in my left eye some thirty years ago when I was 35 (Reason for such early cataract is not known – I do not have diabetes). No lens was implanted. Later on some 10 years ago, I had a lens implant but the job was botched (Wrong lens was implanted). In the same eye, macula is also damaged perhaps because of some childhood injury. I also use eye drops for glaucoma in both eyes. Now I need to have cataract surgery in my right eye. My doctor says that he will need to put a weak lens in this eye so as to balance it with the left eye. It means that my good eye will also be -7. My left eye is -10. For some reason he did not suggest improving the left eye’s sight through piggyback lens or Lasik, at least to correct for the wrong implant, and, at that time I did not know about these options. I will certainly ask him about these options before proceeding with any surgery on my right eye. Regardless, I feel quite uncomfortable about the weakening of the good eye. Is my concern legitimate or am I overreacting?Any advice would be most helpful.
title: Botched Cataract Surgery
